Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with sloping sides; underside decorated (likely stamped) with representation of stylised male figure possibly holding a stick (?) and to left a cross-shaped sign; pierced through diameter; bright turquoise glaze, bit damaged; pale yellow core.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This motif is not listed in Gorton 1996, but the cross-shaped sign is commonly found on scarabs and scaraboids produced at 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). It is usually seen as a debased hieroglyphic sign (see examples in Gorton 1996, 105-106, type XXVIII C). This scaraboid is closer to Gorton's type XXVIII B than XXVIII C, since the stamped motif is not arranged in register composition. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.032) (phase 3)
Condition: Relatively fair though glaze slightly damaged
